questions.question: The ability of a postsynaptic neuron to respond to the presence of a particular neurotransmitter that is released from a neighboring presynaptic neuron is dependent on which of the following conditions?

options.A: The storage of the neurotransmitter in the presynaptic neuron
options.B: The ability of the neurotransmitter to penetrate the membrane of the postsynaptic neuron
options.C: The presence of receptors on the postsynaptic neuron that have an affinity for that particular neurotransmitter
options.D: Whether or not the neurotransmitter is excitatory or inhibitory
options.E: Whether or not the postsynaptic neuron has an axon that is myelinated

questions.question: Organizing the string of letters B-F-J-T-A-V-K-C into JFK-TV-CAB is an example of
When persuasive communications follow the peripheral route, they focus on which of the following?
Consider the sentence 'The dishwasher is running.' Which of the following is true?

options.A: It can have more than one surface structure.
options.B: It can have more than one deep structure.
options.D: It can have more than one syntax.
options.E: It violates the rules of bottom-up processing.

questions.question: According to the Diagnostic and Statistical Manual of Mental Disorders, DSM-5-TR, children with separation anxiety disorder often experience which of the following symptoms in addition to excessive fear or anxiety over separation from attachment figures?

options.A: Excessive concern about the safety and wellbeing of attachment figures
options.B: Persistent desire to develop relationships with adults other than those who serve as major attachment figures
options.C: Pervasive anxiety about failure in school or social situations
options.D: Perceptual delusions that the child’s parents have been replaced by physically identical imposters
options.E: Irresistible urges to perform and repeat a certain act over and over again

questions.question: Patients with bilateral damage to the hippocampal formation are tested on motor learning tasks such as the Tower of Hanoi. Studies show that the patients improve their performance with repeated exposures. When asked whether they have ever seen the task, even after numerous test sessions with it, they typically report not having seen it before. Such results have led to which of the following conclusions?

options.A: Patients with hippocampal injury suffer from confabulation similar to Korsakoff’s patients.
options.B: The inability to remember the Tower of Hanoi reflects a fundamental lesion-induced inability to name objects.
options.C: Although procedural memory may not rely on normal hippocampal functioning, declarative memory does.
options.D: Hippocampal injury enhances the acquisition of tasks relying on motor learning.
options.E: Whereas procedural memory is severely impaired after hippocampal injury, reference memory is intact.

questions.question: Which of the following is chemically similar to opiates, has the ability to reduce pain, and is blocked by the action of naloxone?
When stress is prolonged, the most likely result is

options.A: generalized weakening of the immune system
options.B: damage to brain areas within the pons and medulla
options.C: an increase in the level of naturally produced endorphins
options.D: intensification of the effects of natural killer cells
options.E: an increase in the number of T cells

questions.question: Which of the following best characterizes an infant’s object concept at six months of age?

options.A: The infant’s visual system is too immature to enable focusing on an object in the visual field.
options.B: The infant is unable to track moving objects in the visual field.
options.C: The infant is not surprised when two objects are seen to occupy the same space at the same time.
options.D: The infant’s understanding of object mechanics is as sophisticated as the adult’s understanding.
options.E: The infant understands objects to be solid bounded entities that take up space and move on continuous paths.

questions.question: A 40-item vocabulary test was administered to a group of students. A second, similar test of vocabulary terms was administered to this same group of students approximately one week later. The researcher reported that the correlation between these two tests was r = .90. What type of reliability is represented in this example?
Which of the following describes the pattern of findings displayed in the graph?

options.A: Men who heard the jazz piece and women who heard the operatic piece scored higher on the mood inventory than those in the other two groups.
options.B: People who heard the operatic piece scored higher on the mood inventory than those who heard the jazz piece.
options.C: People who heard the jazz piece scored higher on the mood inventory than those who heard the operatic piece.
options.D: Men scored higher than women on the mood inventory regardless of the type of music they heard.
options.E: Women scored higher than men on the mood inventory regardless of the type of music they heard.

questions.question: The researcher concludes from her study that jazz music positively changes men’s moods and operatic music positively changes women’s moods. Which of the following invalidates that conclusion?

options.A: The participants were college students who were not music majors.
options.B: Only one scale was used to measure mood.
options.C: Men and women were randomly assigned to groups.
options.D: Previous studies have shown that men are less emotional than women.
options.E: Men’s and women’s moods were not measured before exposure to the two types of music.

questions.question: Which of the following is the most serious problem with the methodology of this research?

options.A: Men and women did not listen to both types of music.
options.B: The singers were not the same gender.
options.C: The sample size was too small to draw a valid conclusion.
options.E: Only one type of music should have been used.

questions.question: The preference for a loosely knit social framework in which individuals are responsible only for the care of their children and themselves is known as

Over many trials a puff of air aimed at JoAnne’s eyes is paired with a loud noise and a subtle smell. Afterward, it is very likely that JoAnne’s conditioned eye blink will be under the control of the loud noise and not the subtle smell. This phenomenon is an example of
The idea that people cope with stress by moving toward people, away from people, or against people is most consistent with the views of
Which of the following is the best example of the categorical perception of human speech?

options.A: Listeners are able to categorize speech samples in terms of the gender of the speaker.
options.B: Listeners are able to categorize a stream of words into a series of distinct words, because they can identify the brief pauses that appear between words.
options.C: When a sound is presented that is intermediate between the phonemes /b/ and /p/, listeners report that they heard either a distinct /b/ or a distinct /p/.
options.D: During speech perception, listeners automatically place phonemes into one of two categories, vowels or consonants.
options.E: After hearing a sentence, people process each word and make decisions about the word’s function within that sentence.

questions.question: Charles Scott Sherrington proposed that rapid stimulation of a specific synapse is likely to produce a cumulative effect in the postsynaptic cell because of
Which of the following is an atypical developmental pattern characterized by stereotyped motor responses and poor communication skills?
The sharing of information about oneself is referred to as
Research on children’s social behavior shows that relative to young adolescent boys, young adolescent girls exhibit more of which type of aggression?
The visual pathway that tells us what we are looking at is called the
Which theorist revised Sigmund Freud’s stages of development, replacing Freud’s psychosexual stages with psychosocial stages?

Using a pendulum apparatus, a participant attempts to derive the physical laws that determine the rate at which a pendulum swings. The participant’s approach to solving this problem is to hold a relevant factor (X) constant and to vary a second relevant factor (Y), and then to reverse this procedure by holding Y constant and varying X. According to Jean Piaget, the participant’s level of cognitive functioning is most likely
A child has just developed the ability to lie with the intention of deceiving another person. This new ability is probably based most directly on a change in the child’s
Rapid eye movements are most closely associated with which of the following?
If a psychological disorder has a genetic basis, one would expect to find the highest concordance rate for the illness between which of the following?
All of the following statements about psychodynamic theorists are correct EXCEPT:

options.A: Karen Horney stressed the importance of social relationships between children and their parents.
options.B: Alfred Adler claimed that childhood feelings of inferiority lead to striving for superiority.
options.C: Carl Jung identified two components of the unconscious: the preconscious and the formal unconscious.
options.D: Erik Erikson described conflicts at different stages of development.
options.E: Sigmund Freud stressed the interaction of the id, the ego, and the superego.

questions.question: Juanita’s classmates enjoy being with her because she is always sociable, easygoing, and lively. On Eysenck’s basic personality dimensions, she would be classified as
Annette is looking for a psychotherapist whose clinical work is rooted in object relations theory. The best match for Annette would be a therapist who emphasizes
What pattern of results on the depression questionnaire would justify the conclusion that sleeplessness leads to depression?

options.A: Normal sleep control < yoked control = depressed
options.B: Normal sleep control = yoked control = depressed
options.C: Normal sleep control = yoked control < depressed
options.D: Yoked control < normal sleep control < depressed
options.E: Yoked control < normal sleep control = depressed

questions.question: What pattern of results on the depression questionnaire would one expect if depression were to arise for reasons other than sleeplessness?

options.A: Normal sleep control < yoked control = depressed
options.B: Normal sleep control = yoked control = depressed
options.C: Normal sleep control = yoked control < depressed
options.D: Yoked control < normal sleep control < depressed
options.E: Yoked control < normal sleep control = depressed

questions.question: Suppose that the results were consistent with the hypothesis that sleeplessness does not lead to depression. Of the following, which would be the most serious criticism of the study and its conclusion?

options.A: Although the questionnaire to measure depression was known to be valid, it may not have been reliable.
options.B: The study failed to examine other factors that might also contribute to depression.
options.D: One week of sleep deprivation may have been inadequate to produce depression.
options.E: The normal sleep-control group was unnecessary.

questions.question: Which of the following predictions is reasonable based on Baddeley and Hitch’s theory of working memory?

options.A: If two tasks using the same component are done concurrently, performance will be improved on one or both.
options.B: If two tasks using the same component are done concurrently, performance will be impaired on one or both.
options.C: If two tasks that do not use the same component are done concurrently, performance will be improved on one or both.
options.D: If two tasks that do not use the same component are done concurrently, performance will be impaired on one or both.
options.E: If two tasks are done concurrently, whether or not they use the same component, performance will be unchanged.

questions.question: Which of the following was the first to systematically and empirically study memory by developing an innovative approach based on consonant-vowel-consonant combinations?
Which memory store is believed to have the largest capacity?
The use of polite words such as 'please' and 'thank you' in everyday speech is called
Which of the following factors would best explain why monozygotic twins, raised together, nevertheless develop different personalities?
Which of the following visual experiences most attracts a newborn’s gaze?

Edmundo got into an argument with the grocery clerk. When he returned to his car after shopping, he discovered that he received a parking ticket. Edmundo furiously crumpled up the ticket and threw it on the ground. When his friend Terri told him to calm down, he screamed at her to mind her own business. Which of the following theories best accounts for Edmundo’s behavior?

Cleotha finds out that her roommate Leontyne is a better pool player than she is. However, Cleotha reminds herself that she can play poker better than Leontyne. Cleotha is engaging in which of the following?
According to the theory of cognitive development proposed by Lev Vygotsky, children learn best by working
According to Jean Piaget, young infants are in which stage of development?

Fred was keenly interested in a new science fiction film and therefore was surprised when he arrived at the theater on opening night and found only a few people there. Fred’s mistaken judgment of the popularity of the film illustrates
According to the evolutionary principle of kin selection, people are more likely to help someone who
An individual suffering from damage to Wernicke’s area would most likely exhibit which of the following behaviors?

options.B: An inability to determine what is socially acceptable behavior
options.C: An explosive temper with even slight provocation
options.D: An inability to form new memories
options.E: An uncontrollable tremor of the hands

questions.question: A fixed action pattern is defined as a response to a

Based on research by Mary Ainsworth, which of the following best describes how an infant who has formed a secure maternal attachment would be expected to respond to the mother’s leaving and/or returning?

options.A: Upon the mother’s return, the infant will be pleased to see her and will go to her to be held.
options.B: Upon the mother’s return, the infant will cry and will cling to her.
options.C: Upon the mother’s return, the infant will actively avoid her.
options.D: The infant will not be upset by the mother’s leaving and will not go to the mother upon her return.
options.E: The infant will cry and cling to the mother as she leaves and will continue to cry throughout the mother’s absence.

questions.question: Damaging the suprachiasmatic nucleus of the hypothalamus in rats will

options.A: impair the ability to acquire spatial information
options.B: reduce the threshold for pain resulting from injury to the limbs
options.C: promote the development of maternal behavior in males
options.D: interfere with the biological clock that is synchronized with light
options.E: decrease aggressive behavior directed at rats of the same sex

questions.question: Aunt Sybil paid her first visit to her niece Angela when the baby was 3 months old. Aunt Sybil enjoyed holding and playing with the baby. Aunt Sybil visited again when Angela was 9 months old. She was dismayed when the little girl took one look at her and burst into tears. Angela was exhibiting a normal emotional reaction called
Which of the following therapeutic techniques can be explained by classical conditioning principles?
Joe’s therapist frequently exhibits genuineness and empathy toward Joe. These elements are defining features of which of the following therapeutic approaches?

Georgia sees a sign in the bathroom stall that says, 'Do not write on the walls under any circumstances!' Georgia takes out her pen and begins to write all over the walls. According to social psychologists, Georgia is experiencing
The tendency to attribute your successes to dispositional factors and your failures to situational factors is called the
What term is best used to describe the smallest meaningful unit of a language?
According to Johnston and Heinz’s multimode theory of attention, why is it dangerous to drive an automobile while talking on a cell phone?

options.A: Driving is an automatic task, but talking requires attentional resources.
options.B: Talking on the phone results in the filtering of all other stimuli, including those relevant to driving.
options.C: People can both talk and drive effectively, but they will not be able to remember anything about either the phone conversation or events related to driving.
options.D: Both talking and driving require attentional resources, and adequate attentional resources may not be allocated to driving.
options.E: Talking is an automatic task, but attentional resources need to be allocated to driving.

questions.question: The transformation of energy into electrical impulses is
The action potential is triggered at which of the following parts of a neuron?
What function is served by the white myelin sheath that may cover an axon?

options.A: It protects the axon from overheating.
options.B: It protects the axon from microorganisms.
options.C: It increases the speed of the electrical impulses.
options.D: It provides the axon with nutrients.
options.E: It prohibits the axon from carrying impulses.

questions.question: Which of the following is the name given to the process of differentiating oneself from others by emphasizing one’s uniqueness?
Which of the following theories places the greatest emphasis on the effects of early childhood experiences on personality?
A neuron that receives excitation from other neurons and conducts impulses from its soma in the spinal cord to muscle or gland cells is called a
The inability to recognize a once-familiar face, while still being able to accurately describe elements of the face, is a characteristic symptom of
Ability derived directly from previous experience is known as
Cohorts born in different decades have been found to differ in their personality characteristics during adolescence. Such findings most directly suggest that personality development

options.A: follows a different course for males and for females during late childhood
options.B: is influenced primarily by hormonal factors
options.C: is based on experience during a critical period in early childhood
options.D: is influenced by the historical context in which it occurs
options.E: is influenced more by peers than by parents during adolescence

questions.question: Of several responses made to the same situation, those which are accompanied or closely followed by satisfaction to the animal will, other things being equal, be more firmly connected with the situation... ; those which are accompanied or closely followed by discomfort to the animal will, other things being equal, have their connections with that situation weakened.
Which of the following best represents Michael’s mental disorder according to the diathesis-stress model?

options.A: Diathesis: Genetic history of schizophrenia; Stress: Death of his mother
options.B: Diathesis: Death of his mother; Stress: Genetic history of schizophrenia
options.C: Diathesis: Genetic history of schizophrenia; Stress: Paranoid beliefs
options.D: Diathesis: Death of his mother; Stress: Paranoid beliefs
options.E: Diathesis: Dropping out of college; Stress: Death of his mother

questions.question: Michael’s false belief that the cashiers were plotting against him is an example of
Michael reported that he harmed the cashier in response to an instruction from his dead mother. This phenomenon is called
Which section of a report would most likely include a description of Michael’s life experiences that are relevant to his mental disorder?
In the case of Michael, which of the following statements is true regarding the positive and negative symptoms of schizophrenia?

options.A: Hearing voices is a positive symptom.
options.B: The fact that Michael’s grandfather had schizophrenia is a positive symptom.
options.C: The perception of his mother instructing him to harm the cashier is a negative symptom.
options.D: Michael’s vehement refusal to take medication is a negative symptom.
options.E: Michael’s unhealthy diet is a negative symptom.

questions.question: Which of the following approaches to assessment of intelligence is most consistent with the theories of both Howard Gardner and Robert Sternberg?

options.A: Using biological indexes of intelligence instead of the Stanford-Binet IQ test
options.B: Narrowing the definition of intelligence to include fewer key skill areas
options.C: Increasing the reliability of IQ tests
options.D: Increasing the emphasis on measuring g rather than specific abilities
options.E: Increasing the emphasis on measuring specific abilities rather than g

questions.question: Which of the following are two competing theories of color vision that describe events that take place at different levels of the nervous system?

Smokers were randomly assigned to one of two groups. Those in the experimental group were told that they would be listening to tapes with subliminal messages urging them to quit smoking. Those in the control group did not listen to the tapes, nor were they told about them. A week after listening to the tapes, members of the experimental group had decreased their smoking significantly more than members of the control group. The investigator concluded that listening to the subliminal messages reduces smoking. Which of the following, if true, casts the greatest doubt on the investigator’s conclusion?

options.A: During the week, some participants in the control group read articles on the hazards of smoking.
options.B: During the week, only a few of the experimental participants reduced their smoking appreciably.
options.C: Participants in the experimental group were influenced by their expectations of the tapes’ effects.
options.D: The two groups had similar initial (baseline) smoking rates.
options.E: The two groups were both quite large, but unequal in size.

questions.question: A researcher conducted a study to determine the effects of gender and status on the perceived credibility of an eyewitness testifying in a trial. Participants watched one of four video recordings depicting the eyewitness and rated the credibility of the eyewitness. What type of design was used in this study?
In order to determine whether gender, as a specific variable, had an effect on perceived credibility of the eyewitness, which of the following must be significant?

options.B: A post hoc analysis of gender
options.D: A post hoc analysis of status
options.E: The interaction between gender and status

questions.question: Damage to which area of the brain leads to a decrease in physically aggressive behavior and social rank?

Consider the following version of an interference task. As fast as possible, say how many items are in each row for set 1 and for set 2. Set 1: $$$ # ** &&&& Set 2: 222 5 44 3333. If participants can say how many items are in set 1 faster than they can say how many are in set 2, the result is most consistent with
Researchers using a variety of methods, peoples, and cultures have concluded that five major personality traits exist. The traits are

options.A: sociability, suspiciousness, practicality, dependency, and shyness
options.B: enthusiasm, calmness, adventure, docility, and hypochondria
options.C: extraversion, agreeableness, conscientiousness, emotional stability, and openness to experience
options.D: obedience, self-control, astuteness, tension, and self-criticism
options.E: emotional stability, apprehension, social awareness, independence, and avoidance

questions.question: Mel is doing very well academically in college, but feels academically incompetent. His therapist has instructed him to explain in writing how his hard work and personal abilities contributed to each of the good grades he received during the previous semester. This activity is characteristic of which of the following therapeutic approaches?
The Flynn effect is the phenomenon of

options.A: the gradual increase in IQ scores over the last century
options.B: higher IQ scores among children who were breast-fed
options.C: higher IQ scores among people with higher levels of education
options.D: a stronger correlation between the IQ scores of monozygotic twins than between those of dizygotic twins
options.E: a stronger correlation between the IQ scores of siblings reared together than between those of siblings reared apart

questions.question: In which of the following cognitive tasks do the performances of older adults show the greatest difference compared to the scores of young adults?
According to current conceptions, working memory is characterized by

options.A: stress on episodic rather than semantic memory
options.C: maintenance of information in current use
options.D: greater importance for procedural than for declarative memory

questions.question: Before taking an exam, Sinead imagines that she will get the worst grade in the class, even though she usually performs very well. Imagining the worst seems to help her deal with the anxiety associated with the exam. What term best describes Sinead’s strategy?
Which of the following techniques of studying the brain involves the use of x-rays?
Damage to the lateral hypothalamus of rats is known to produce deficits in regulation of
According to a current model, learned helplessness in humans is determined by causal explanations of prior uncontrollable events. These causal explanations are referred to as
Amyloid plaques and neurofibrillary tangles are most often characteristic of
Albert recently noticed that he has difficulty hearing people at crowded parties even though his hearing seems fine in quiet surroundings. He most likely has damage to his

John recently moved to a large city and experienced an increase in the level of noise. His new home was located adjacent to a railroad track. The rail service was frequent and maintained a consistent schedule. John was awakened frequently each night as trains passed his home. However, after several months he was not awakened and he became less aware of the trains passing by his home. What mechanism accounts for John’s adaptation to his environment?
Which of the following is a chronic condition that can cause anterograde amnesia in some people?
Lo is an advocate of personal construct theory. Which of the following processes does Lo believe are most important in the study of personality?
According to Albert Bandura’s approach to observational learning, which of the following is the best example of vicarious punishment?

options.A: A child stops throwing pencils after watching a teacher scold another child for throwing a pencil across the room.
options.B: A child watches a teacher say to another child, 'You did so well on that homework that you do not need to take the test tomorrow.'
options.C: A child acquires a schema about the difference between socially punished behavior and socially rewarded behavior.
options.D: A child escapes punishment by cleaning up a mess before anyone notices it.
options.E: A child is punished on a variable ratio schedule, rather than being punished every time a mistake is made.

questions.question: Cephalocaudal development refers to development that proceeds from
Which of the following best states the major shortcomings of the place and the frequency-matching (volley) theories of audition?

options.A: Neither theory can be studied empirically.
options.B: Initial evidence in support of these theories cannot be replicated.
options.C: Neither theory can account for auditory disorders that are caused by structural defects in the temporal lobe.
options.D: Place theory applies primarily to loud sounds, whereas frequency-matching theory applies primarily to barely audible sounds.
options.E: Place theory does not explain the coding of very low frequencies, whereas frequency-matching theory does not explain the coding of very high frequencies.

questions.question: Which of the following represents the correct order of stages in Bibb Latané and John Darley’s model of helping?

options.A: I. Interpretation, III. Noticing, V. Deciding to help, IV. Perception of responsibility, II. Knowing how to help
options.B: III. Noticing, I. Interpretation, IV. Perception of responsibility, II. Knowing how to help, V. Deciding to help
options.C: III. Noticing, IV. Perception of responsibility, I. Interpretation, II. Knowing how to help, V. Deciding to help
options.D: III. Noticing, IV. Perception of responsibility, II. Knowing how to help, V. Deciding to help, I. Interpretation
options.E: III. Noticing, IV. Perception of responsibility, I. Interpretation, V. Deciding to help, II. Knowing how to help

questions.question: What is a limitation of Elisabeth Kübler-Ross’s stages of coping with death (denial, anger, bargaining, depression, and acceptance)?

options.A: The stages are not relevant to terminally ill patients.
options.B: The stages are based on a study with fewer than twenty individuals.
options.C: Not all people experience every stage.
options.D: Few people in Western cultures experience the depression stage.
options.E: The stages are generally not relevant to younger adults.

questions.question: Which of the following statements about subliminal messages is most accurate?

options.A: Visual messages are more effective than auditory messages in influencing attitude and behavior change.
options.B: There is evidence they can influence short-term attitude change.
options.C: They are one of the most common techniques used by advertisers to influence attitude and behavior change.
options.D: They are more effective than personal testimonial advertising campaigns in influencing attitude and behavior change.
options.E: They are consciously perceived by participants nearly 100% of the time.

questions.question: Brain imaging techniques have shown that compared to unaffected individuals, individuals diagnosed with schizophrenia have

options.A: enlarged ventricles and a reduction of the prefrontal cortex
options.B: reduced ventricles and a reduction of the parietal cortex
options.C: an enlarged parietal cortex and a reduction of the hypothalamus
options.D: lesions in the parietal lobe and increased cells in the orbital frontal cortex
options.E: lesions in the temporal lobe and increased cells in the prefrontal cortex

questions.question: Research by Solomon Asch supports which of the following?

options.A: Conformity increases as group size increases from two people to four or five people.
options.B: The presence of one dissenter in a group is not strong enough to reduce conformity.
options.C: Higher levels of conformity are found in individualistic societies than in collectivist societies.
options.D: A person’s behavior changes when that person plays a role as a prisoner or prison guard in an experiment.
options.E: Individuals will follow orders to shock innocent strangers.

questions.question: In which of Erik Erikson’s psychosocial stages of development is the central task to develop and exercise self-control and independence?

A recent article in an educational journal described a university at which the average age is 26. This article also mentioned that 38 percent of the students are over 25 years of age. What can be concluded from this information?

options.A: The median age must be greater than the mean age.
options.B: The standard deviation must be relatively small.
options.C: The mode must be either 25 or 26.

questions.question: Which of the following concepts does the figure above illustrate?

An experimenter predicts that bright colors enhance creativity. She provides brightly colored crayons to the first 15 children who show up for an experiment and muted colored crayons for the remaining 15. She then examines their drawings and judges the brightly colored drawings to be more creative. The study is flawed because it lacks

options.A: a double-blind procedure and an independent variable
options.B: an independent variable and demand characteristics
options.C: demand characteristics and a dependent variable
options.D: a dependent variable and random assignment
options.E: random assignment and a double-blind procedure

questions.question: Which of the following is an example of a self-conscious emotion?
A behavioral approach to personality would argue that the root of pathology lies in

Five randomly selected groups of participants are shown a list of words, one word at a time. Each group of participants is assigned a different task to perform on each word on the list. After completing the list, the participants are given a surprise test for recall of the words. Which of the following assigned tasks is most likely to result in the best recall?

options.A: Counting the number of vowels in each of the words
options.B: Indicating whether each of the words contains the letter 't'
options.C: Producing a rhyme for each of the words
options.D: Saying each of the words three times in rapid succession
options.E: Producing a synonym for each of the words

questions.question: In a lexical decision task, two groups of participants are instructed to make a fast decision on whether each item is or is not an English word. The first group of participants is presented with the word 'robin,' followed by the word 'bird.' The second group is presented with the word 'chair,' followed by the word 'bird.' The first group’s responses to 'bird' will most likely be

options.C: slower because of a sequence effect

questions.question: The antianxiety effects of benzodiazepines such as diazepam result from their binding with the receptor for which of the following neurotransmitters found in the amygdala?
A persistent, unreasonable, and unwanted thought is known as
Which of the following distinguishes experts from novices in many fields of endeavor?

options.B: Speed in recognizing relevant complex patterns
options.C: Innate talent for performing in the particular field
options.E: Shorter reaction times to simple stimuli

questions.question: Consider the diagram above in which the outcomes for two people (Joanne and Malik) are represented as a series of numbers, depending on their own behavior and the behavior of the other person. A scientist uses these outcomes to predict the likely behavior of each of the individuals. The scientist is most likely studying which of the following?
Eliciting sympathy in order to create a positive impression is consistent with which of the following self-presentation strategies?
Which of the following statements describes normative influence?

options.A: The process by which we come to evaluate and know others
options.B: The tendency for impressions of others to be heavily influenced by information gathered early in an interaction
options.C: A set of theories describing how people explain causes of behavior
options.D: Conformity motivated by a fear of social rejection
options.E: Conformity motivated by the belief that others are correct

questions.question: Which of the following hormones is responsible for preparing the uterus for the implantation of an ovum that has been fertilized?
An adolescent who says, 'I won’t become ill from smoking; I never get sick,' is most likely operating under which aspect of egocentrism?
Alfred Adler developed his theory of individual psychology as a result of his disagreement with which of the following?

options.A: Carl Roger’s belief that human growth is dependent on unconditional positive regard
options.B: Sigmund Freud’s emphasis on universal biological forces in the personality
options.C: Albert Bandura’s focus on reciprocal determinism as a key factor in shaping personality
options.D: Gordon Allport’s belief that personality is made up of individual fundamental traits
options.E: Abraham Maslow’s emphasis on a hierarchy of needs in creating motivation

questions.question: Which school of psychology rejected the concept of consciousness and defined psychology as an objective natural science?
Which of the following is a memory store that is highly sensitive to masking stimuli presented within 200–300 milliseconds of the presentation of an array of letters?
The neural hub of the central executive portion of working memory is thought to be located in the

In an experimental procedure, an animal receives a half second of foot shock, then a half second of no stimulus, and then a tone. In a later presentation of the tone, the animal displays a fear response. This result most likely indicates the occurrence of
The full Moon looks much larger when it is on the horizon than when it is high in the sky. Which of the following is the best explanation for this phenomenon?

options.A: More rods are stimulated by the Moon when it is just above the horizon than when it is high in the sky.
options.B: Size judgment is based on visual cues between the viewer and the image of the Moon.
options.C: Brightness constancy cues are disrupted by interfering stimulation.
options.D: The image of the Moon high in the sky exceeds the difference threshold.
options.E: Judgment is based on the Gestalt principle of proximity.

questions.question: Which of the following philosophers insisted that the mind at birth is like a blank slate devoid of character or ideas?
The overjustification effect states which of the following?

options.A: Positive reinforcement is consistently more effective than negative reinforcement.
options.B: Extrinsic rewards can diminish children’s intrinsic motivation to learn.
options.C: Extrinsic rewards are best when used with intrinsically motivated students.
options.D: Academic grades increase students’ intrinsic motivation to learn.
options.E: Behavior modification improves internal motivation in large classrooms.

questions.question: The belief that differences among spoken languages cause differences in the thinking and problem-solving styles of speakers is called
Which of the following is the correct sequence of stages of prenatal development?

Participants in a social psychological experiment observe through a one-way glass as two students take an oral quiz. The situation is arranged such that both Arthur and Sheri get 15 of the 25 questions correct, but Arthur gets each of the first 5 questions correct, while Sheri gets none of the first 5 correct. Most participant observers would likely conclude that

options.A: Arthur is a better student than Sheri
options.B: Sheri is a better student than Arthur
options.C: Arthur and Sheri are approximately equally able students
options.D: The experiment does not provide any information about the ability of Arthur or Sheri
options.E: Arthur and Sheri are confederates in the experiment

questions.question: The confirmation bias leads people to draw incorrect conclusions because they

options.A: use algorithms when they should use heuristics
options.B: use deductive reasoning when they should use inductive reasoning
options.C: do not seek evidence that would disprove their hypotheses
options.D: do not consider alternative uses for a well-known object
options.E: mistakenly attribute the causes of other people’s behavior to internal factors

questions.question: Dr. Wang is a theorist who is interested in how a given behavior increases an organism’s chance of reproductive success and perpetuates the species. Dr. Wang is most likely
In his study of schizophrenia, Dr. Perez collects data on the number of new cases of this diagnosis in the United States in the past year. This statistic is known as the

A security screener in an airport checks by hand everything that seems suspicious. It is critical that she never let any potentially dangerous item through her security checkpoint. In terms of signal detection theory, this screener is likely to make

options.A: a large number of misses and a small number of hits
options.B: a large number of hits and a large number of false alarms
options.C: a large number of misses and a large number of false alarms
options.D: a small number of hits and a small number of false alarms
options.E: a large number of correct rejections and a large number of false alarms

questions.question: The Premack principle states that

options.A: a more frequent behavior will reinforce a less frequent behavior
options.B: intrinsic motivation is reduced when it is overused
options.C: there is a contingent relationship between stimulus and response
options.D: reinforcement is illusory when it is noncontingent

questions.question: Elizabeth Loftus and her colleagues ask students to talk about various events that have occurred in their lives, including one that never occurred. If the students have trouble remembering, the researchers provide cues. They record whether the students remember the events that never occurred and how confident the students are in these false memories. Which of the following best describes the findings?

options.A: About 25% of the students remember the false event, and many are quite confident in it.
options.B: Students almost never remember false events, although they remember about 80% of the real events.
options.C: About 80% of the students remember the false event, but their confidence is uniformly low.
options.D: Students almost never remember false events, and their memory for the actual events is also quite low.
options.E: False memories can be implanted in about 40% of the students, but these memories are forgotten within about a week.

questions.question: Melvin has a set of Von Frey hairs of different diameters. He starts by pressing a thin hair against a participant’s toe and continues with increasingly thicker hairs until the participant feels pressure. Melvin then starts with a thick hair and uses increasingly thinner hairs until the participant does not feel pressure. Melvin is using the method of
Long-term potentiation is widely assumed to be the physiological mechanism of
Roberta lives on the first floor of her dorm. She notices that she has made more friends with others who live on her floor than with others on other floors. This is an example of

Some researchers believe that people acquire a second language better if they learn it prior to adolescence, whereas other researchers believe that people can easily learn most aspects of a second language, even if they are beyond adolescence. However, based on the most frequently observed limitation in second language use, both groups would expect to observe less than native-like competence after adolescence in which of the following?
The legal requirement that professionals notify appropriate authorities about suspected child abuse is known as

A researcher conducted a study to determine the effects of gender and status on the perceived credibility of an eyewitness testifying in a trial. Participants watched one of four video recordings depicting the eyewitness and rated the credibility of the eyewitness.
In order to determine whether gender, as a specific variable, had an effect on perceived credibility of the eyewitness, which of the following must be significant?

options.B: A post hoc analysis of gender
options.D: A post hoc analysis of status
options.E: The interaction between gender and status

questions.question: Damage to which area of the brain leads to a decrease in physically aggressive behavior and social rank?

Dr. Chen is interested in feminist attitudes of young adult women in the United States. Consequently, she administered a feminist attitude questionnaire to a total of 100 young adult women from three universities. The 100 women tested and the number of young adult women in the United States are which of the following, respectively?
Which of the following are the two individuals credited with the founding of psychology, as indicated by the formation of psychology laboratories in the 1870s?

options.C: Gustav Fechner and E. B. Titchener

questions.question: A researcher investigating the effects of a certain medication found that individuals taking the drug performed better on a memory task than those taking a placebo. However, performance gains were only significant for those with low memory ability before treatment. This finding is an example of
